item.title: The Handmaiden
item.description: This movie is Rashomon meets Oldboy meets a Tinto Brass. There is something disturbing about Korean thriller films. It’s perhaps exaggerated by my lack of knowledge of the Korean culture, it feels very alien, disconnected, happenning in a shadow world, fragmented, a snowstorm in a crystal ball. In The Handmaiden this is further amplified by the setting. The movie starts with a scene in a poverty-riden Korean, immediately contrasted with a serene dreamlike scene following a lonely car through a famous-five island, on a curving road, through through woods and darkness and distictly Japanese gardens.
